elements.content: A new azido-NiII complex constructed from nicotinate has been obtained by cation−anion pairs as templates under hydrothermal conditions, which exhibits three-dimensional Kagomé topology and ferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: A new azido-NiII complex constructed from nicotinate has been obtained by cation-anion pairs as templates under hydrothermal conditions, which exhibits three-dimensional Kagomé topology and ferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content:
A rare three-dimensional Kagomé metal−organic coordination polymer of NiII-azido complex showing ferromagnetic coupling has been synthesized and characterized.

Metal−organic coordination polymers have become an interesting topic in inorganic chemistry not only because of their multifunctional properties such as gas storage, optical devices, and magnetism, but also because of their intriguing molecular networks and elegant topologies. Design and synthesis of intriguing structural frameworks with aimed properties, especially in the study of magneto-structural correlations, are now very popular. One of the intensely explored frameworks in molecule-based magnetism is the geometrically frustrated two-dimensional (2D) Kagomé lattice. If spins are half-odd-integer in magnitude, it highly caused frustration, while for integer spins or mixed-spin, the frustration is almost absent and this can even give rise to ferro/ferrimagnetic interactions. Compared to the intensely explored 2D Kagomé lattice, to our knowledge, there is only one example of a three-dimensional (3D) Kagomé framework exhibiting antiferromagnetic coupling, which was mathematically predicted as net sqc876, reported by LaDuca recently.
elements.clean_text:
A rare three-dimensional Kagomé metal-organic coordination polymer of NiII-azido complex showing ferromagnetic coupling has been synthesized and characterized.

Metal-organic coordination polymers have become an interesting topic in inorganic chemistry not only because of their multifunctional properties such as gas storage, optical devices, and magnetism, but also because of their intriguing molecular networks and elegant topologies. Design and synthesis of intriguing structural frameworks with aimed properties, especially in the study of magneto-structural correlations, are now very popular. One of the intensely explored frameworks in molecule-based magnetism is the geometrically frustrated two-dimensional (2D) Kagomé lattice. If spins are half-odd-integer in magnitude, it highly caused frustration, while for integer spins or mixed-spin, the frustration is almost absent and this can even give rise to ferro/ferrimagnetic interactions. Compared to the intensely explored 2D Kagomé lattice, to our knowledge, there is only one example of a three-dimensional (3D) Kagomé framework exhibiting antiferromagnetic coupling, which was mathematically predicted as net sqc876, reported by LaDuca recently.

elements.content: As we know, azide as a short bridging ligand, which can provide rich coordination modes and efficient pathways of magnetic exchange, and hence affect the spin ground state of a molecule, has been widely used in magnetochemistry, but it is rarely reported in the studies of materials with Kagomé structure. On the other hand, charged species are not always present in coordination polymer cavities. Furthermore, the complex with both cation and anion in the same cavities is quite uncommon.
elements.clean_text: As we know, azide as a short bridging ligand, which can provide rich coordination modes and efficient pathways of magnetic exchange, and hence affect the spin ground state of a molecule, has been widely used in magnetochemistry, but it is rarely reported in the studies of materials with Kagomé structure. On the other hand, charged species are not always present in coordination polymer cavities. Furthermore, the complex with both cation and anion in the same cavities is quite uncommon.

elements.content: (a) The linkage and coordination mode in 1. NiII ions are shown as dark green, C as light green, O as red, and N as blue. Symmetry mode A: 4/3 − x, 5/3 − y, 2/3 − z. (b) Two kinds of hydrogen bonds in 1: N−H···O hydrogen bonds between [Ni(H2O)6]2+ and azides are shown as blue; O−H···O hydrogen bonds between OH− and O1W are shown as red (similar hydrogen bonds between OH− and O2W were omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The linkage and coordination mode in 1. NiII ions are shown as dark green, C as light green, O as red, and N as blue. Symmetry mode A: 4/3 - x, 5/3 - y, 2/3 - z. (b) Two kinds of hydrogen bonds in 1: N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between [Ni(H2O)6]2+ and azides are shown as blue; O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between OH- and O1W are shown as red (similar hydrogen bonds between OH- and O2W were omitted for clarity).

elements.content: Herein, we present a rare 3D Kagomé framework of NiII-azido complex exhibiting ferromagnetic coupling, {Ni12(N3)12(L)12(H2O)6·[Ni(H2O)6]2+·(OH−)2} n (1) (L = nicotinate), with cation−anion pairs by hydrogen bonds interactions in the cavities, synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we present a rare 3D Kagomé framework of NiII-azido complex exhibiting ferromagnetic coupling, {Ni12(N3)12(L)12(H2O)6⋅[Ni(H2O)6]2+⋅(OH-)2} n  (1) (L = nicotinate), with cation-anion pairs by hydrogen bonds interactions in the cavities, synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of NaN3, NiCl2·6H2O, and nicotinic acid at 140 °C gave green crystals of 1. The phase purity of 1 was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) () and elemental analysis. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction of 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the rhombohedral space group and has a 3D framework structure (Figure a). There are three crystallographically independent NiII ions. Ni(1) is hexacoordinated by three oxygen atoms and three nitrogen atoms as meridianal arrangement. Two of the oxygen atoms are from nicotinate ligands [Ni1−O3 = 2.013(3) Å, Ni1−O2 = 2.035(3) Å], and one from a coordinated water molecule [Ni1−O1W = 2.108(4) Å]. Two of the N atoms from cis-azide ions coordinate with Ni(1) via μ1,1 mode [Ni1−N1 = 2.193(3) Å] and μ1,1,1 mode [Ni1−N4 = 2.128(3) Å], respectively, and another N atom is from the third nicotinate ligand [Ni1−N7 = 2.103(3) Å]. Ni(2) is hexacoordinated by two cis-oxygen atoms from two nicotinate ligands [Ni2−O4 = 2.039(3) Å, Ni2−O1A = 2.044(3) Å], three nitrogen atoms from μ1,1 mode azide ion [Ni2−N1 = 2.166(3) Å] and μ1,1,1 mode azide ions [Ni2−N4 = 2.126(3) Å, Ni2−N4A = 2.152(3) Å], and another nitrogen atom from another nicotinate ligand [Ni2−N8 = 2.049(3) Å]. Ni(3) is described as [Ni(H2O)6]2+ with N−H···O hydrogen bonds between [Ni(H2O)6]2+ and azides as a template in the assembly process of this 3D network (Figure b), and the OH− counterions with O−H···O hydrogen bonds to coordinated water molecules O1W and O2W located in the cavities of this framework.
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of NaN3, NiCl2⋅6H2O, and nicotinic acid at 140 °C gave green crystals of 1. The phase purity of 1 was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) () and elemental analysis. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction of 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the rhombohedral space group and has a 3D framework structure (Figure a). There are three crystallographically independent NiII ions. Ni(1) is hexacoordinated by three oxygen atoms and three nitrogen atoms as meridianal arrangement. Two of the oxygen atoms are from nicotinate ligands [Ni1-O3 = 2.013(3) Å, Ni1-O2 = 2.035(3) Å], and one from a coordinated water molecule [Ni1-O1W = 2.108(4) Å]. Two of the N atoms from cis-azide ions coordinate with Ni(1) via μ1,1 mode [Ni1-N1 = 2.193(3) Å] and μ1,1,1 mode [Ni1-N4 = 2.128(3) Å], respectively, and another N atom is from the third nicotinate ligand [Ni1-N7 = 2.103(3) Å]. Ni(2) is hexacoordinated by two cis-oxygen atoms from two nicotinate ligands [Ni2-O4 = 2.039(3) Å, Ni2-O1A = 2.044(3) Å], three nitrogen atoms from μ1,1 mode azide ion [Ni2-N1 = 2.166(3) Å] and μ1,1,1 mode azide ions [Ni2-N4 = 2.126(3) Å, Ni2-N4A = 2.152(3) Å], and another nitrogen atom from another nicotinate ligand [Ni2-N8 = 2.049(3) Å]. Ni(3) is described as [Ni(H2O)6]2+ with N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between [Ni(H2O)6]2+ and azides as a template in the assembly process of this 3D network (Figure b), and the OH- counterions with O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds to coordinated water molecules O1W and O2W located in the cavities of this framework.

elements.content: Two μ1,1 mode azides and two μ1,1,1 mode azides bridge Ni1/Ni2/Ni2A/Ni1A, as the tetranuclear [Ni4] entity shown in Figure a. Considering the centroids of the tetranuclear [Ni4] entity as connecting nodes, and eight L ligands connecting different tetranuclear [Ni4] entities by their nitrogen atoms and carboxylate groups, the network of 1 can be described as a 8-connected 3D 364125862 (sqc876) topology (Figure b), evocative of a rare 3D Kagomé lattice.
elements.clean_text: Two μ1,1 mode azides and two μ1,1,1 mode azides bridge Ni1/Ni2/Ni2A/Ni1A, as the tetranuclear [Ni4] entity shown in Figure a. Considering the centroids of the tetranuclear [Ni4] entity as connecting nodes, and eight L ligands connecting different tetranuclear [Ni4] entities by their nitrogen atoms and carboxylate groups, the network of 1 can be described as a 8-connected 3D 364125862 (sqc876) topology (Figure b), evocative of a rare 3D Kagomé lattice.

elements.content: (a) The tetranuclear [Ni4] entity in 1. (b) Schematic representation of 3D Kagomé lattice in 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The tetranuclear [Ni4] entity in 1. (b) Schematic representation of 3D Kagomé lattice in 1.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility data were collected for crushed crystalline samples of 1. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility was measured at 1 kOe in the 3−300 K temperature range for 1 (Figure a). All of the magnetic data has been analyzed using the asymmetric unit from a magnetic point of view which contains one tetranuclear [Ni4] and one-third mononuclear NiII. To analyze the magnetic structure, the spin coupling scheme for ferromagnetic [Ni4] is shown in Figure a. The value of χm T for one tetranuclear [Ni4] and one-third mononuclear NiII at 300 K is 5.89 cm3 K mol−1, which is slightly larger than that expected for four and one-third NiII ions with S = 1, indicating the presence of predominant ferromagnetic interactions in 1. On cooling the χm T value increases gradually until it increases to 9.91 cm3 K mol−1 at 28 K, and below 28 K, it decreases quickly to 5.12 cm3 K mol−1 at 3 K, which might be mainly due to the presence of zero-field splitting (ZFS) for NiII ions. Fitting of the χm −1 − T above 50 K using the Curie−Weiss law χm = C/(T − θ) gives the Curie constants C = 5.60 cm3 K mol−1 and the Weiss constants θ = 19.57 K, which support the presence of overall ferromagnetic interactions in the complex. The nicotinate ligands that link the tetranuclear [Ni4] to form 3D net will provide a pathway for weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The magnetic coupling through this ligand in this bridging Ĥ = − 2 J 1 ( Ŝ 1 Ŝ 2 ) − 2 J 2 ( Ŝ 1 Ŝ 3 + Ŝ 2 Ŝ 4 ) − 2 J 3 ( Ŝ 1 Ŝ 4 + Ŝ 2 Ŝ 3 ) + D ∑ i = 1 4 Ŝ i z 2 + μ B g B ∑ i = 1 4 Ŝ i z mode is very weak and usually antiferromagnetic. The magnetic data of 1 is simulated based on the spin Hamiltonians in eq , using the package MAGPACK, where D is the ZFS parameter. J 1 corresponds to the interaction between the pair of metal ions bridged by two μ1,1,1-azide groups, J 2 represents the spin coupling between metal centers bridged by a μ1,1,1-azide and a carboxylate group, and J 3 refers to the spin coupling between Ni1 and Ni2 bridged by a μ1,1-azide, a μ1,1,1-azide and a carboxylate group. Using this rough model, the best-fit parameters obtained are J 1 = 11.5 cm−1, J 2 = 5.0 cm−1, J 3 = 7.0 cm−1, and D = 3.0 cm−1 with g = 2.1. The bridge angles of μ1,1-azide often control exchange coupling. In 1, the ferromagnetic coupling J 1 between Ni2 and Ni2A bridged by two μ1,1,1-azide groups is expected with the Ni2−N4−Ni2A angle of 94.83°. The weakened ferromagnetic contribution for J 2 and J 3 might be a small antiferromagnetic term exchanged via carboxylate groups. The reduced molar magnetization at 2 K (Figure b) corroborates the ferromagnetic coupling in tetranuclear [Ni4] entities: the M/Nβ value at 7 T is close to 8.86 Nβ.

The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility was measured at 1 kOe in the 3-300 K temperature range for 1 (Figure a). All of the magnetic data has been analyzed using the asymmetric unit from a magnetic point of view which contains one tetranuclear [Ni4] and one-third mononuclear NiII. To analyze the magnetic structure, the spin coupling scheme for ferromagnetic [Ni4] is shown in Figure a. The value of χm T for one tetranuclear [Ni4] and one-third mononuclear NiII at 300 K is 5.89 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly larger than that expected for four and one-third NiII ions with S = 1, indicating the presence of predominant ferromagnetic interactions in 1. On cooling the χm T value increases gradually until it increases to 9.91 cm3 K mol-1 at 28 K, and below 28 K, it decreases quickly to 5.12 cm3 K mol-1 at 3 K, which might be mainly due to the presence of zero-field splitting (ZFS) for NiII ions. Fitting of the χm -1 - T above 50 K using the Curie-Weiss law χm = C/(T - θ) gives the Curie constants C = 5.60 cm3 K mol-1 and the Weiss constants θ = 19.57 K, which support the presence of overall ferromagnetic interactions in the complex. The nicotinate ligands that link the tetranuclear [Ni4] to form 3D net will provide a pathway for weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The magnetic coupling through this ligand in this bridging 1  Ĥ = - 2   J   1    (    Ŝ   1     Ŝ   2    )  - 2   J   2    (    Ŝ   1     Ŝ   3   +   Ŝ   2     Ŝ   4    )  - 2   J   3    (    Ŝ   1     Ŝ   4   +   Ŝ   2     Ŝ   3    )  + D   ∑   i = 1   4      Ŝ   i z   2   +   μ   B   g B    ∑   i = 1   4      Ŝ   i z     mode is very weak and usually antiferromagnetic. The magnetic data of 1 is simulated based on the spin Hamiltonians in eq , using the package MAGPACK, where D is the ZFS parameter. J 1 corresponds to the interaction between the pair of metal ions bridged by two μ1,1,1-azide groups, J 2 represents the spin coupling between metal centers bridged by a μ1,1,1-azide and a carboxylate group, and J 3 refers to the spin coupling between Ni1 and Ni2 bridged by a μ1,1-azide, a μ1,1,1-azide and a carboxylate group. Using this rough model, the best-fit parameters obtained are J 1 = 11.5 cm-1, J 2 = 5.0 cm-1, J 3 = 7.0 cm-1, and D = 3.0 cm-1 with g = 2.1. The bridge angles of μ1,1-azide often control exchange coupling. In 1, the ferromagnetic coupling J 1 between Ni2 and Ni2A bridged by two μ1,1,1-azide groups is expected with the Ni2-N4-Ni2A angle of 94.83°. The weakened ferromagnetic contribution for J 2 and J 3 might be a small antiferromagnetic term exchanged via carboxylate groups. The reduced molar magnetization at 2 K (Figure b) corroborates the ferromagnetic coupling in tetranuclear [Ni4] entities: the M/Nβ value at 7 T is close to 8.86 Nβ.

elements.content: (a) χm T vs T plot for 1. Inset: the spin coupling scheme. (b) Plot of the reduced magnetization at 2 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) χm T vs T plot for 1. Inset: the spin coupling scheme. (b) Plot of the reduced magnetization at 2 K.

elements.content: In summary, a new 3D Kagomé NiII-azido compound with OH− counterions and templated by [Ni(H2O)6]2+ has been synthesized and characterized. It is dominated by ferromagnetic coupling along its tetranuclear [Ni4] entities.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a new 3D Kagomé NiII-azido compound with OH- counterions and templated by [Ni(H2O)6]2+ has been synthesized and characterized. It is dominated by ferromagnetic coupling along its tetranuclear [Ni4] entities.

elements.content:
X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format for 1 and a PDF file including Figure S1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

Synthesis of 1: Complex 1 was prepared by hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of NaN3, NiCl2·6H2O, nicotinic acid at a ratio of 2:1.5:1 in 15 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 140 °C for 2 days under autogenous pressure, and then cooled to room temperature. Green block crystals of 1 were harvested in ca. 40% yield. Anal. Calcd. for 1: C, 28.99; H, 2.50; N, 22.54. Found: C, 28.68; H, 2.70; N, 22.39. CAUTION: Although not encountered in our experiments, azido compounds of metal ions are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of the materials should be prepared, and it should be handled with care.

metadata.title: A New Azido-Nickel Compound with Three-Dimensional Kagomé Topology
